Shots, explosions ,the rattle of machine gun fire, whistles, sirens, and the
Raymond Scott-like hum of a power plant will burst forth from the ordinarily quiet stage of the Auditorium theater when the Barnstormers
present their annual play on December 16, 1939. Ernst Toiler's "No
More Peace", this year's presentation, contains more unusual features
than any other production ever offered to the public by the Barnstormers. The play, because of its
theme dealing with the destruction
of war, gave rise to many unexpected
production problems.
These dilemmas, naturally, had to
be solved with as little cost and with
the best results possible. Time and
time again the master minds of Al
Agrin and Vic Victoroff, not to mention those of the entire production
staff, were stumped. However, in this
case, as in almost all cases, ingenuity
was triumphant. Devices that have
never before been used on the Barnstormers' or any other stage will be
used to produce the necessary sound
effects. How many pails of flash
bulbs and explosive powder will be
consumed and how many plates of
glass will be broken, and what number of shots will be fired must, of
course, remain a mystery until the
actual presentation. However, one
thing is certain. "No More Peace"
will offer the greatest amount of action that its producer's can put into it.
Nevertheless, not all the problems
of production were concerned with
sound effects. A mysterious poison
gas had to be developed and it was,
indeed. The lighting effects demanded
a great deal of thought and care.

drafted. Francis, a sophomore, had
previously had much experience with
lighting effects in the summer stock

'Truth, Democracy
casualties of war',
says Buttrick
Dr George Buttrick, pastor of the
Madison Avenue Presbyterian church,
New York city, spoke on "American
Good Will and the World Crisis" at
the third meeting of the University
lecture series. He said that all nations are equally guilty of this war
and advised Americans to keep poise,
sanity, and perspective. According to
him we should not keep out ears
glued to the radio nor should we
devour propaganda about the war.
The first casualty in war is truth,
the second, democracy. The people
are like a tuning fork, if it is constantly hammered it loses pitch.
We must view the foreign situation in an unprejudiced light and
remember that Europe is not a monopoly of vice and that the United
States is not a monopoly of virtues.
European blood flows in our veins
and although we seem more peaceful,
the reason is that we are separated
from them.
In order to stay out of war, Dr
Buttrick said, "Keep resolute good
will and the determination to understand . . . The German people are
especially essentially human and
characteristically kind."

Dr Sidney Painter, acting chairman
of the Social Science group, announced the change in policy after a
meeting of the fifteen faculty members in the group was held last
Tuesday, December 5.
The complete announcement contained three provisions:
"(1) That there will be a reading
period extending for three weeks
from the beginning of the second
term (February 1 to February 22)
during which all classes composed
chiefly of Juniors and Seniors shall
be suspended.
"(2) That Juniors are to be given
such special reading as the instructor
may consider best suited to their
needs.
"(3) That any instructor who does
not consider it advisable to suspend
his courses may hold classes during
the reading period."
Although, according to the third
provision, classes may be held during
this year's reading period as in the
past, the inclusion of Juniors in the
plan will lessen the number of classes
held, it is believed. Formerly, with
Juniors excluded from the readiiig
period, classes falling under t',e
jurisdiction of the Social Science
group were largely made up of nonSeniors.
"The plan is an experiment," said
Dr Painter. "The group hopes that
the inclusion of Juniors will serve a
double purpose—Juniors will be given
a chance to read books outside the
regular reading for specific courses
and Seniors will be able to devote
more time to work for which the
reading period was introduced if
fewer classes are held."

Six new appointments to the Honor commission were announced last

Cluster, incumbent president. These

chosen at the last meeting of the
commission Thursday, at which

AB students; Pete Stern, an Engineering student; and Morty Hack

the commission were made.

definite schedule of meetings for

Dr Kent Roberts Greenfield, acting as chairman at the International
Relation club's symposium on world
affairs last Saturday, placed two
general questions before the six men
present at the speakers' table. Opening the discussion on "A program
for Peace after the Present War",
he asked "What kind of peace do we
require as a nation?" and "To what
extent is such a peace possible?"
At the morning session, Which
lasted from 10:30 to 12:30, Dr W
Stull Holt, professor of American
history; Dr A 0 Lovejoy, professor
emeritus of philosophy; and Dr Franz
Michael, of the Page school of international relations, discussed the
American point of view towards a
peace and the general question of the
struggle between liberty and authority in creating a state of international system for Europe.
"Obviously we want peace", said
Dr Holt, who opened the discussion, "and most public opinion would
like to see peace with justice. Most
of all the present administration
would like to see the world organized so that wars are kept at a minimum. There has been no clear indication of how America will pay the
price for a peace it wants. But the
essential thing is to adopt some kind
of a program if we want peace."
Questions from the other speakers
and from the floor followed Dr Holt's
introductory remarks; the general
point of the discussion centered
around the advisability of the United
States' entering the war, and the
probable effect of such an action on
this country's bargaining power in
the peace conference. Dr Holt contended that, "if the dictators win,
we will become more dictatorial. If
the world continues on this basis,
we will be involved in this war or
some future one. We will overcome
this trend if we act now, and at
the same time, we will make unnecessary paying a higher price for

By Charles Weiland
"Since Maxcy left, the place has
been quiet; it just isn't the same,"
mourned Sandy, alias Sandy Di Stefano, the sole proprietor of Hopkins'
exclusive establishment catering to
the campus clip and snip trade—
barber shop to you, buddy.
Sandy, who has been a barber since
he was nine years old, boasts numerous customers, all acquired since
he greeted his first client in the little
shop in Levering hall two years ago.
He counts both students and faculty
among his clientele, and is even on
such terms of intimacy with some of
the latter that the conversation is
conducted in Sandy's beloved Italian.
But ,regardless of the loss of the
vociferous Mr Maxcy, the campus
barbershop continues to be the scene
of boisterous activities rivaling those
of Shakespeare's clowns.
"The trouble," confided Sandy, "usually starts when Handelsman gets his
hair cut, which, I might add for the
benefit of business might be oftener.
Then Ed Kassan and Toy Swerdloff
and Hecht and a few others drop in
and start to help me shave Handelsman, and before I know it, the place
is one mad-house. Bah!" But he was
smiling as he ended.
The peculiarities of his customers
are always of interest to Sandy.
"Some of the boys like rhythm haircuts", he disclosed, and added a novel
demonstration by swaying back and
forth and stropping a razor in rhythm

with the radio. It seems that two of
the Hopkins students most addicted to
these jitterbug cuttings are the redoubtable Henry Anthony and the
inimitable George Newton. "That
Tony just loves it," said Sandy.
Other novel facts of the Hopkins
clip and snip trade are that only
seven of Sandy's customers get German haircuts, while most student
barberees prefer to read rather than
smoke. The radio is always popular.
Conversation is popular with only
about half of his clients, Sandy revealed. "The professors talk about
foreign affairs and economics, and
almost always ask me what I think
about Europe, but I say, get Hitler
and Mussolini and Chamberlain and
Daladier together in a room and let
'em shoot it out," grinned Sandy.
Student conversation, on the other
hand, revolves almost entirely about
girls and dates. "Girls, girls, girls,
dames, that's all I hear!" he grimaced in mock despair. Questioned
concerning what ye olde ed Handelsman talks about, Sandy characterized
it as "unprintable."
Sandy himself has his own preferences. Glenn Miller is his favorite
orchestra, and eating his favorite
occupation. He eats breakfast at
home, lunch at Hopkins, another afternoon snack at three o'clock, dinner at home, and a final meal at
about eight o'clock in the evening.

Dr Joseph T Singewald, eminent
Johns Hopkins university geologist,
will discuss the economic balance of
power in Europe and the rest of the
world in terms of natural resources
and mineral deposits at the second
assembly of the current Peace series.
This assembly, being given jointly by
the NEWS-LETTER and Tau Beta Pi,
will co-star with Dr Singewald's discussion the semi-annual Tau Beta Pi
tap.
The assembly will be held on Thursday, December 18 at 11:30. Tau Beta
Pi will tap six men.
Tau Beta Pi, the engineering Phi
Beta Kappa, was founded at Lehigh
university in 1885. The organizer, for
E H Williams, wanted to unite the
outstanding students of the engineer
school in a brotherhood. Selection of
members is based on character, leadership, personality, scholarship, and
participation in extra-curricular activities. At Hopkins, the Alpha chapter was founded in 1919. Only juniors
in the upper eighth and seniors in the
upper quarter of their class are eligible. Aside from this scholastic
standing, most of the other requirements must be filled in order to be
considered by the fraternity.
Dr Joseph Theophilus Singewald,
jr, has been associated with the Hopkins since he graduated from Baltimore City college in 1904. He became
an associate in economic geology, and
rose to the position of Professor of
Geology at the University in 1924.

One good thing about
Hopkins is that it has a
faculty which seems to
avoid studiously the practice of going around making remarks in public about
the state of education and
what ought to be done about it. Compared with University of Chicago students for instance, who probably never know what their charming but occasionally
disconcerting Dr Hutchins will suggest next, students
at Hopkins have much to be thankful for.
And one of the things they ought to be especially
thankful for is the new reading period plan. This
plan doesn't have the air of a scheme conceived by
an educational wizard; somehow most schemes which
startle at first become dead letters within a year or
two. It looks more as if this plan were a sincere
effort on the part of the Social Science group to do
away with a few difficulties which arose when reading
periods were begun in the University about seven or
eight years ago.
Seniors now have a better chance of being relieved from the pressure of making up work or from
giving up part of the reading period to attend classes;

with both Juniors and Seniors included in the plan,
more classes will have majorities of those who can
take advantage of the obviously valuable reading
period.
To Juniors in the Social Science group, the plan
is of even more value. From one point of view,
which is too often disregarded, the Junior year in
college is as important as, if not more important than,
the Senior year. It is in the Junior year that a
general synthesizing of knowledge must take place.
The first two years of a college curriculum are devoted to survey courses, introduction to new lines of
thought, and a general reorientation of views along
more mature lines than those presented in prep schools.
The senior year is devoted to final work for a degree.
Standing in between, the Junior year presents an excellent opportunity for examination of what has gone
before and for work in anticipation of what is to
come.
All too often, Juniors come to realize that some
one phase of study has been neglected, that this or
that book should have been read, or that some special
work ought to be done in preparation for the future.
Even if he realizes this, the Junior seldom has time
to do more than keep up with his regular reading.
A reading period for at least the Social Science
Juniors will come as a happy solution to many of
these problems.
We can't make out this
year's crop of seniors. For
weeks they battled to have
their Hullabaloo assured;
they were willing to promise
anything—well, almost anything if they could but have
permanent record of their final year at Hopkins. The
offenses, to hear the senior speak, were that the yearbook staff was inefficient, the officers didn't- cooperate
with one another, the Administration was interfering,
etc, etc.
Well, they finally got their Hullabaloo, and sat
down and rubbed their hands over the "victory."
Now, now when the coast is clear, and the photographers and staff are busy, they avoid their appointments for pictures as if the soliciting agent was an
insurance salesman.
The associate editors as well as the other members of the staff who have arranged the myriad details
connected with the senior pictures know all the nasty
things one can say about "inefficiency . .. no cooperation . . independability . . . etc." Those boys know
all the old cracks and have invented sixteen new ones.
And if the seniors don't get down to their appointments on time there will be another senior assembly—
at which all the seniors will sit on the platform, and
the Hullabaloo staff will heckle them from the audience.
All we can say is, it's
about time. And we do mean
the Honor commission. Why
appointments haven't been
made until the beginning of
December to a group which
is supposed to keep the Honor system constantly before students is more than we
can fathom.
Add to that the fact that "no definite schedule of
meetings . . has been announced by the commission
as yet" and a pretty sorry picture emerges. And
the same old propaganda comes out of the commission; that is, when it comes at all. "It is just as
much a part of the honor system to report a violation
as it is to avoid personal violation". Well, we know
that, and have known it for a long time.
Time was when the Honor commission filled the
NEWS-LETTER with stories—not because the paper was
being used for propaganda purposes, but because the
commission was news. Now it gets about as much
space as the League of Nations in the daily press.
Short gasps, but nothing more, and those infrequent.
It's a far cry from the commission as first founded
year before last to today's commission. That first
group may have been enthusiastic because it was new,
but it at least did something. It introduced the slip
system, and began to build up an attitude quite different
from that held by the sub-Student council Engineering Honor commission. That bunch of Honor system
cossacks was formed to play an only slightly minor
role to the Student council's czar. It's job was to
ferret out offenders and run them down.
The AB and Business Honor commission brought a
new and, we feel, a better attitude into play in enforcing the Honor system. No trials were held. The
new commission was strictly an educational body.
And it worked.
But it can't be kept going unless there is constant
work. Appointments should -have been made at the
beginning of the year; meetings should be held every
week; and, above all, the Honor system should be
kept before the whole school all year long.
We don't know whose fault it is, but we suspect the
Honor commission. Last year, a commission flourished even with part of the Student council in favor of
doing away with. This year, the Student council is
more than ready to support the commission, but there's
nothing to support. No plans, no publicity.
It looks as if the commission needs more going
over than just appointing new members.

How to put more and more wires into a telephone cable
without increasing its diameter is an ever present problem
at Western Electric—manufacturing unit of the Bell
System. Existing ducts beneath city streets limit both the
number and the diameter of cables—but demand for telephone service continues to grow.
Until recently, the largest cable contained 3636 wires
in a diameter of 25/8 inches. Years of study led to an entirely new insulating process that saved 3/1000 of an inch
per wire. Multiply this tiny fraction of an inch by 3636,
and you provide enough space to place 606 more wires
in the same size cable!—a total of 4242.
With such resourcefulness, Bell System engineers meet
countless problems. Result: you can talk to almost anyone, anywhere—quickly, at low cost.

How to put more and more wires into a telephone cable
without increasing its diameter is an ever present problem

in a diameter of 25/8 inches. Years of study led to an entirely new insulating process that saved 3/1000 of an inch
per wire. Multiply this tiny fraction of an inch by 3636,
and you provide enough space to place 606 more wires
in the same size cable!—a total of 4242.
With such resourcefulness, Bell System engineers meet
countless problems. Result: you can talk to almost anyone, anywhere—quickly, at low cost.
